Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Assessing the Effect of Environmental Stressors on Invertebrate Innate Immunity using a Coral Pathosystem
Award.AbstractNarration:
Mydlarz, Laura IOS-1017458

LiT: Collaborative Research: Assessing the effect of environmental stressors on invertebrate innate immunity using a coral pathosystem.

The abundance of reef-building corals has declined dramatically over the last decades. The main causes of coral loss are related to ocean warming, nutrient pollution and disease outbreaks, all resulting from anthropogenic-induced climate change. Observations indicate that number and prevalence of coral diseases have increased over the last two decades and new epizootics nearly every year suggest that environmental stressors drive or exacerbate coral disease. This project will examine coral resistance to pathogens and variation in innate immunity, as well as quantify the effects of ocean warming and nutrient pollution on the effectiveness of coral immune responses. The project will focus on the Montastraea faveolata Yellow Band Disease (YBD) system. The genus Montastraea is one of the most important groups of corals of modern western Atlantic coral reefs, however, Montastraea spp. populations have declined dramatically mainly due to bleaching and disease.

Using assays for cellular and cell-free processes in coral immunity, the PIs will examine the variability in disease resistance in naturally infected corals, the reaction time and recovery time from temperature stress and how the combination of stressors influence coral immunity in the presence of YBD pathogens. This project will also train undergraduates and graduate students at multiple universities, and promote exchange between four universities. Funding will support a novel service-learning project. Undergraduate students from an upper-level marine biology course will prepare and execute a lesson plan for junior high school students based on concepts from their course and this project. One of the investigators on this project will collaborate with professional educators and outreach specialists at a Planetarium and a public-oriented Science Center to develop an interactive museum display and K-4 summer camp programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
More than 100 countries worldwide have coral reefs along their coastlines and tens of millions of people depend on coral reefs for part of their livelihood and protein intake. Even though coral reefs cover less than 1% of the ocean floor (255.000 km2), they are the most productive and biologically diverse marine ecosystems providing a variety of important ecological/social services to a vast number of humans. Reefs provide habitat, refuges and energy to resident and transient species that move across these communities, many of them commercially important, reefs are reservoirs of biodiversity and major sinks of CO2, regulating chemical balances (pH) in coastal and oceanic waters. More than 10% of fish consumed by humans comes from these communities; they reduce coastal erosion and protect coastal areas from storms and hurricanes, generate white sand, provide building material, chemically active compounds for pharmacological products, recreation as well as aesthetic, social and cultural benefits.

However, coral reef deterioration has increased globally over the last several decades due to the combination of natural and direct/indirect anthropogenic threats, and is seriously compromising the future integrity and function of these communities, hampering their ability to provide the ecosystem’s goods and services that many people rely upon today. In the Caribbean for example, live coral cover has declined from an average 50% in the 1970s to less than 15% today. Several factors are responsible, but biotic diseases and temperature-induced bleaching events rank as the top factors accelerating the decline of coral reefs Worldwide. Both factors are related to the increase in seawater temperature and high temperature anomalies linked to Global Warming. Every reef is different and despite widespread recognition that the World’s coral reefs are seriously threatened, information regarding which threats, and how they affect reef organisms and the community is limited, hampering our understanding of the processes and conservation efforts.

This project goals were to use several novel complementary research and outreach approaches, including field information, controlled experiments and ecological immunology, to aide in our understanding of coral disease resistance and/or susceptibility, their immune responses, variability and adaptability in Caribbean reef-building corals. The subjects of our research included one of the most important reef-building coral species in the region as a model, the star coral Orbicella faveolata, This species has shown to be highly susceptible to environmentally- (thermal stress) and biologically- (pathogens) induced diseases. It has experienced high local and geographic widespread mortality caused by thermally induced bleaching events and several new and virulent diseases like white plague disease (WPD) and Caribbean yellow band disease (CYBD).

Overall, results of this project increased our understanding of the innate immune system in scleractinian corals, what are the genetic responses, how it works, how it responds to environmental stressors, such as the high temperatures expected during the current trend of Global warming, and how it might have evolved.
